edu.rit.util

Class Instance

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.util.Instance

  • public class Instance
extends Object
    Class Instance provides static methods for creating instances of classes.

    • Method Detail

      • newInstance

        public static Object newInstance(String s)
                          throws ClassNotFoundException,
                                 NoSuchMethodException,
                                 InstantiationException,
                                 IllegalAccessException,
                                 InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of a class as specified by the given string. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newInstance(s,false). See the newInstance(String,boolean) method for further information.
        Parameters:
        s - Constructor expression string.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if s does not obey the required syntax.
        ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the given class cannot be found.
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if a suitable constructor cannot be found in the given class.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the given constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the given constructor throws an exception.

      • newInstance

        public static Object newInstance(String s,
                 boolean disableAccessChecks)
                          throws ClassNotFoundException,
                                 NoSuchMethodException,
                                 InstantiationException,
                                 IllegalAccessException,
                                 InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of a class as specified by the given string. The string must consist of a fully-qualified class name, a left parenthesis, zero or more comma-separated arguments, and a right parenthesis. No whitespace is allowed.

        The newInstance() method deduces the data type and value of each argument provided in the constructor expression according to the following patterns:

        • Optional + or -; 0b or 0B; one or more digits 0 through 1 — binary (base-2) value of type int.

        • Optional + or -; 0x or 0X; one or more digits 0 through 9, a through f, or A through F — hexadecimal (base-16) value of type int.

        • Optional + or -; 0; zero or more digits 0 through 7 — octal (base-8) value of type int.

        • Optional + or -; a digit 1 through 9; zero or more digits 0 through 9 — decimal value of type int.

        • Optional + or -; 0b or 0B; one or more digits 0 through 1; l or L — binary (base-2) value of type long.

        • Optional + or -; 0x or 0X; one or more digits 0 through 9, a through f, or A through F; l or L — hexadecimal (base-16) value of type long.

        • Optional + or -; 0; zero or more digits 0 through 7; l or L — octal (base-8) value of type long.

        • Optional + or -; a digit 1 through 9; zero or more digits 0 through 9; l or L — decimal value of type long.

        • Otherwise — type String.

        If a decimal argument is outside the range of type int or type long, the deduced value is not specified. If a binary, octal, or hexadecimal argument is larger than 32 bits for type int or 64 bits for type long, the deduced value is not specified.

        The newInstance() method attempts to find a constructor for the given class as follows, where N is the number of provided arguments:

        • If N = 0, use a no-argument constructor.

        • Else if there is a constructor with N arguments whose types match those provided, use that constructor.

        • Else if all provided arguments are of type int and there is a constructor with one argument of type int[], use that constructor.

        • Else if all provided arguments are of type long and there is a constructor with one argument of type long[], use that constructor.

        • Else if there is a constructor with N arguments of type String, use that constructor; all provided arguments are passed as strings.

        • Else if there is a constructor with one argument of type String[], use that constructor; all provided arguments are passed as strings.

        • Else throw a NoSuchMethodException.

        The newInstance() method invokes the chosen constructor, passing in the provided argument values, and returns a reference to the newly-created instance.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's pertinent constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Note: To find the given class, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        s - Constructor expression string.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if s does not obey the required syntax.
        ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the given class cannot be found.
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if a suitable constructor cannot be found in the given class.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static Object newDefaultInstance(String className)
                                 throws ClassNotFoundException,
                                        NoSuchMethodException,
                                        InstantiationException,
                                        IllegalAccessException,
                                        InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the class with the given name using the class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newDefaultInstance(className,false). See the newDefaultInstance(String,boolean) method for further information.

        Note: To find the class with the given name, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        className - Class name.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the class with the given name cannot be found.
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static Object newDefaultInstance(String className,
                        boolean disableAccessChecks)
                                 throws ClassNotFoundException,
                                        NoSuchMethodException,
                                        InstantiationException,
                                        IllegalAccessException,
                                        InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the class with the given name using the class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the new instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Note: To find the class with the given name, the calling thread's context class loader is used.

        Parameters:
        className - Class name.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        ClassNotFoundException - Thrown if the class with the given name cannot be found.
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static <T> T newDefaultInstance(Class<T> c)
                            throws NoSuchMethodException,
                                   InstantiationException,
                                   IllegalAccessException,
                                   InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the given class using the class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling newDefaultInstance(c,false). See the newDefaultInstance(Class,boolean) method for further information.
        Type Parameters:
        T - Class's data type.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • newDefaultInstance

        public static <T> T newDefaultInstance(Class<T> c,
                       boolean disableAccessChecks)
                            throws NoSuchMethodException,
                                   InstantiationException,
                                   IllegalAccessException,
                                   InvocationTargetException
        Create a new instance of the given class using the class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing the new instance. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Type Parameters:
        T - Class's data type.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        New instance.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the given class does not have a default constructor.
        InstantiationException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the given class is an interface or an abstract class.
        IllegalAccessException - Thrown if an instance cannot be created because the calling method does not have access to the class or constructor.
        InvocationTargetException - Thrown if the constructor throws an exception.

      • getDefaultConstructor

        public static Constructor<?> getDefaultConstructor(Class<?> c)
                                            throws NoSuchMethodException
        Get the given class's default constructor. Calling this method is equivalent to calling getDefaultConstructor(c,false). See the getDefaultConstructor(Class,boolean) method for further information.
        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        Returns:
        Default (no-argument) constructor for the class.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the class does not have a default constructor.

      • getDefaultConstructor

        public static Constructor<?> getDefaultConstructor(Class<?> c,
                                   boolean disableAccessChecks)
                                            throws NoSuchMethodException
        Get the given class's default constructor.

        If the disableAccessChecks argument is true, access checks are suppressed when constructing an instance using the returned constructor. This means the object's class and/or the class's default constructor need not be public, and a new instance will still be constructed. However, this also requires that either (a) a security manager is not installed, or (b) the security manager allows ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks"). See the java.lang.reflect.Constructor.setAccessible() method for further information.

        Parameters:
        c - Class.
        disableAccessChecks - True to disable access checks, false to perform access checks.
        Returns:
        Default (no-argument) constructor for the class.
        Throws:
        NoSuchMethodException - Thrown if the class does not have a default constructor.
